linkTarget.anchoringText: NAMUB Field is a brown field (with approximately 47 years of production) located in the Niger Delta. The Field discovered in 1957 with first oil (NAMB001) achieved in 1971. It is a South-West –North East trending rollover anticline bounded to the North by a major growth fault. The field is dissected by a number of smaller synthetic and antithetic faults which occur at the crest and towards the South-Western part of the field (Figure 1). Hydrocarbons have been found between depths of 7,500 ftss and 12,800 ftss in a stacked series of anticlinal or dip and fault bounded structures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Top Structure Map of E1000 Reservoir.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top Structure Map of E1000 Reservoir.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 2 presents the gas lift candidate selection workflow.

All the shut-in oil wells were screened to know those that have pressure decline above 50%. This was done with the view that reservoirs with significant pressure decline above 50%, will likely not be able to realize their reserves any longer irrespective of Gaslift assistance. There are forty-four shut in oil conduits in the field which were drilled to develop twelve reservoirs. Ten reservoirs are in the main block and two in the northern block. The bar chart (Figure 3) captures their initial reservoir pressures, current pressures and percentage (%) pressure decline.

Material Balance (MBAL) was used for this evaluation. The evaluation also took into consideration the inter-reservoir communication in the E-sands. This was done by utilizing multitank scenarios, thus further providing robustness in the evaluation results. This can be seen in the Multi-tank MBAL architecture (Figure 4)

The terminal water production for each conduit was modelled at 75% BSW with the correspondiong THPs. This exercise was repeated with 95% BSW for gas lift, resulting in an extended well life and higher incremental recovery. Sensitivities were made on different gaslift injection rates to get the optimum gas injection rates. Typical profiles for terminal BSW modelled at 75% and the production sensitivity analysis on BSW without vertical lift assistance and with vertical lift assistance is given in figures 6 and 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Production Sensitivity Analysis on BSW without Vertical Lift Assistance

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Sensitivity Analysis on BSW without Vertical Lift Assistance

linkTarget.anchoringText: The terminal water production for each conduit was modelled at 75% BSW with the correspondiong THPs. This exercise was repeated with 95% BSW for gas lift, resulting in an extended well life and higher incremental recovery. Sensitivities were made on different gaslift injection rates to get the optimum gas injection rates. Typical profiles for terminal BSW modelled at 75% and the production sensitivity analysis on BSW without vertical lift assistance and with vertical lift assistance is given in figures 6 and 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Production Sensitivity Analysis on BSW using Gaslift

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Sensitivity Analysis on BSW using Gaslift

linkTarget.anchoringText: Furthermore, based on the well modelings, the gaslift performance showed that the optimal gaslift Injection for the wells can be reached from 0.8- 2.5 MMscf/d injection rate range. Figure 8 and Table 2 show the gas lift design performance plot and results for one of the conduits.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: NAMB022L Gas Lift Design Performance Plot

formatted-caption.caption-text: NAMB022L Gas Lift Design Performance Plot

linkTarget.anchoringText: After updating the models, wells were history matched again and simulation runs were done. The relevant MBAL plots (Figures 9-12) for a case study reservoir NAMB D6000X which gave us the highest gas lift gain on NAMB021S.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This had to do with incorporating the inter-reservoir communication in the E sands into the Wells, Reservoir & Facility Management (WRFM) space. Emmanuel M. et al (2016) had posited an uncertainty management framework (Figure 14) utilized for inter-reservoir communication evaluation with MBAL.

The economic evaluation incorporated the reserves, incremental resource volume, Gaslift line/flowline costs and ancilliary costs to resuscitate the wells. The worst case scenario well was used to demonstrate its viability (Figure 15). This is because once the well with the lowest volume/ highest cost ranks as viable, it means that all the other wells are economically viable.
